Dobbs |altname= |country= [[United States]] |formercountry= |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1993|8|10|mf=yes}} |birth_place= [[Clovis, California]] |hometown= [[Mission Viejo, California]] |residence= |death_date= |death_place= |height= {{height|ft=5|in=4}} |partner= [[Joseph Jacobsen]] |formerpartner= [[Christopher Trefil]] |coach= [[Todd Sand]]

[[Justin Dillon]]
Cindy Stuart |skating club= Peninsula Skating Club |retired= |combined total= 158.23 |combined date= [[2010 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2010 Four Continents]] |SP score= 57.56 |SP date= [[2010 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2010 Four Continents]] |FS score= 100.67 |FS date= [[2010 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2010 Four Continents]] }} '''Amanda J. Dobbs''' (born August 10, 1993) is an [[United States|American]] [[figure skater]] who has competed as a [[single skater]] and [[pair skater]]. As a single skater, she placed 7th at the [[2008-2009 ISU Junior Grand Prix Final]]. She teamed up with [[Joseph Jacobsen]] in 2009 and began competing with him in pairs while also competing in singles. She competed in both disciplines at the [[2010 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]]. {{As of|2011|04}}, she was ranked 29th in the world by the [[International Skating Union]] (ISU).{{cite web | url = http://www.isuresults.com/ws/ws/wsladies.htm | title = ISU World Standings for Figure Skating and Ice Dance : Ladies | publisher = [[International Skating Union]] | date = 30 April 2011 | accessdate = 3 May 2011}} ==Personal life== Dobbs was born in [[Clovis, California]] and lives in [[Mission Viejo, California]]. She attends [[Laurel Springs School]]. Her uncle played for the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]]. ==Career== ===Early career=== Dobbs began competing in 2003 on the Intermediate level. In 2004, she won the silver medal on the intermediate level at the 2005 Central Pacific Regionals. She also competed in [[pair skating]] with [[Christopher Trefil]] on the intermediate level. They won the pewter medal at the 2005 U.S. Junior Championships. She moved up to the novice level for the 2005â2006 season and placed 7th at her regional championship. with Trefil in pairs, she also competed on the novice level. They won the silver medal at their sectional championship and qualified for the [[2006 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]], where they placed 5th.{{cite web | url = http://stlouis2006.usfigureskating.org/Results.aspx?lv=novice&ds=pairs | title = 2006 State Farm U.S. Figure Skating Championships Novice Pairs Result | date = | accessdate = January 27, 2010 | publisher = [[U.S. Figure Skating]] }} In the 2006â2007 season, she remained on the novice level. She won her regional championship and advanced to her sectional championship, where she placed 6th. In the 2007â2008 season, Dobbs moved up to the junior level. She won her regional championship and won the bronze medal at her sectional championship to qualify for the [[2008 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]], where she placed 5th. She was assigned to the [[2008 International Challenge Cup]], where she won the bronze medal. ===2008â2009 season=== In the 2008â2009 season, Dobbs debuted on the [[ISU Junior Grand Prix]] circuit. At the [[2008-2009 ISU Junior Grand Prix]] event in Mexico, she won the gold medal and was assigned to a second event by [[U.S. Figure Skating]]. At her second event, in South Africa, she won the bronze medal. She qualified in fifth position to the [[2008-2009 ISU Junior Grand Prix Final]].{{cite web | url = http://www.isuresults.com/events/jgp2008/jgpsladies.htm | title = ISU Junior Grand Prix of Figure Skating 2008/2009 Junior Ladies FINAL RESULTS | date = | accessdate = January 27, 2010 | publisher = [[International Skating Union]] }} At the Junior Grand Prix Final, she placed 7th. By qualifying to the Junior Grand Prix Final, she had earned a bye to the [[2009 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]]. Dobbs competed on the junior level and placed 7th. Following that season, Dobbs teamed up with [[Joseph Jacobsen]] to compete in [[pair skating]] while still competing as a single skater. ===2009â2010 season=== In the 2009â2010 season, Dobbs competed in single and pair skating. She made her senior international debut{{cite news | url = http://www.usfigureskating.org/Story.asp?id=43711 | title = Eleven U.S. Athletes to Compete this Week at Ice Challenge in Graz, Austria | date = October 27, 2009 | accessdate = January 27, 2010 | publisher = [[U.S. Figure Skating]] }} at the [[2009 Ice Challenge of Graz]] and won the bronze medal. The timing of this competition gave her a bye through the regional championships to her sectional championships. At the 2010 [[Pacific Coast Sectional Figure Skating Championships]], held in the fall of 2009, Dobbs qualified for the [[2010 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]] by winning the pewter medals in both the singles event and the pairs event. At the 2010 U.S. Championships, Dobbs placed 6th in the ladies event,{{cite web | url = http://www.usfigureskating.org/leaderboard/results/2010/64740/CAT001.html | title = 2010 US Figure Skating Championships 01/15/2010 â 01/23/2010 Championship Ladies Final Results | date = January 23, 2010 | accessdate = January 27, 2010 | publisher = [[U.S. Figure Skating]] }} and 7th in the pairs event{{cite web | url = http://www.usfigureskating.org/leaderboard/results/2010/64740/CAT003.html | title = 2010 US Figure Skating Championships 01/15/2010 â 01/23/2010 Championship Pairs Final Results | date = January 16 | accessdate = January 27, 2010 | publisher = [[U.S. Figure Skating]] }} with Jacobsen. Because the [[2010 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships]] were held so close to the U.S. Championships, U.S. Figure Skating had submitted possible entries in advance. Dobbs was on the alternate list for Four Continents and was assigned to the event following the 2010 U.S. Championships.{{cite news | url = http://www.usfigureskating.org/Story.asp?id=44109&type=media | title = U.S. Figure Skating Announces Ladies, Ice Dancing Teams Nominated to 2010 U.S. Olympic Figure Skating Team | date = January 23, 2010 | accessdate = January 27, 2010 | publisher = [[U.S. Figure Skating]] }} Dobbs & Jacobsen were not listed as alternates and so could not have been sent; but were the fourth alternates for the [[2010 World Figure Skating Championships]].{{cite news | url = http://www.usfigureskating.org/Story.asp?id=44090&type=media | title = U.S. Figure Skating Announces Pairs Teams Nominated to 2010 U.S. Olympic Figure Skating Team | date = January 16, 2010 | accessdate = January 27, 2010 | publisher = [[U.S. Figure Skating]] }} At the Four Continents Championships, she placed second in the short program with 57.56 points, 1.32 behind [[Akiko Suzuki]].{{cite web | url = http://www.isuresults.com/results/fc2010/SEG003.HTM | title = ISU Four Continents Figure Skating Championships â Ladies â Short Program Result Details | date = January 27, 2010 | accessdate = January 27, 2010 | publisher = [[U.S. Figure Skating]] }}{{cite news | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/olympics/winter/2010/figureskating/news/story?id=4862447 | title = Suzuki, Dobbs excel at Four Continents | date = January 27, 2010 | accessdate = January 27, 2010 | publisher = [[Associated Press]] }} She finished fourth overall. ===2010â2011 season=== She has been assigned to the [[2010 Cup of China]]. ==Programs== ===Singles programs=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !
